channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: Guinea coup attempt: Soldiers claim to seize power from Alpha Condé
item.description: Troops announce a takeover on TV, while the defence ministry insists a coup attempt was thwarted.

item.title: Moment boy cuts ribbon too soon at opening ceremony in Turkey
item.description: Turkey's president joked with the boy when he noticed he had jumped the gun at an opening ceremony.

item.title: South Africa's ex-president Zuma granted medical parole
item.description: Jacob Zuma will now serve the remainder of his 15-month sentence in the community.

item.title: Mali police storm jail to free detained commander
item.description: The commander of Mali's anti-terror police is accused of murder during 2020 anti-government protests.

item.title: India farmers' protests: Tens of thousands join rally in Uttar Pradesh
item.description: A vast crowd of protesters, some riding on tractors, rallied in Uttar Pradesh state.

item.title: Yemen war: Saudis intercept Houthi missiles - defence ministry
item.description: Two children are injured by shrapnel, Riyadh says, in an attack the Houthis say targeted Saudi oil.

item.title: Montenegro clashes as Serb Orthodox Church leader installed
item.description: The fierce protests reflect tensions in the country, which broke away from Serbia in 2006.

item.title: Rush to contain large oil spill in Gulf of Mexico after Storm Ida
item.description: Clean-up crews and the US Coast Guard are trying to locate the source of a miles-long slick.

item.title: Ethiopia's Tigray conflict: Thousands reported killed in clashes
item.description: Both the Tigray rebels and Ethiopian military say they have inflicted thousands of casualties.

item.title: New Zealand cinema worker left red-faced after voicemail blooper
item.description: A cinema employee in New Zealand went viral on TikTok with his attempt to leave a voicemail recording.

item.title: US Open: World number one Ashleigh Barty stunned by Shelby Rogers in third round
item.description: World number one Ashleigh Barty falls in the US Open third round after Shelby Rogers produced a superb comeback in front of a raucous New York crowd.

item.title: Paralympics: ‘We the disabled community are here to stay’
item.description: Four champions share their glory and their pain from the 16th Paralympic Games in Tokyo.

item.title: 'I studied law in jail - now I want to change the system'
item.description: LaTonya Myers spent nine months in jail because she couldn’t afford bail - now she's helping others facing the same challenge.

item.title: Hamid Nouri: How Sweden arrested a suspected Iranian war criminal
item.description: Prosecutors have put Hamid Nouri on trial over a 1988 massacre in Iran. This is how they did it.

item.title: Kenyan men join battle to end FGM
item.description: Campaigners say it is important that Kenyan men join the battle to end female genital mutilation.

item.title: Why China's bitcoin miners are moving to Texas
item.description: Beijing's crackdown on cryptocurrency sends bitcoin entrepreneurs moving to the wild wild west.

item.title: German election: Who could succeed Angela Merkel as chancellor?
item.description: A lacklustre lead candidate and a surprisingly strong Social Democrat have blown the race wide open.

item.title: British soldier describes caring for Kabul airport baby
item.description: Lt Col Ben Caesar helped look after the baby who was pulled over the airport wall in Afghanistan.

item.title: 'My parents won't let me get the Covid vaccine'
item.description: In some countries, the Covid-19 vaccine can be given to all teenagers over the age of 12 but not all are allowed.

item.title: ICYMI: Catwalk hail storm and cheeky capybaras
item.description: Some of the stories that you may have missed this week.

item.title: Afghanistan: British Army officers tell of 'chaotic' evacuation operation
item.description: The senior British commander in Kabul speaks for the first time about the UK's evacuation operation.

item.title: Storm Ida aftermath: 'I can't even count my losses from the flooding right now'
item.description: Residents in the US north-east assess the scale of the devastation caused by Tropical Storm Ida.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: Afghanistan women's cricket team: Players hiding in Kabul fear Taliban rule
item.description: Members of Afghanistan's women's cricket team are hiding in Kabul, fearing for their safety following the Taliban's return to power.

item.title: Life under the Taliban: Where is your male escort?
item.description: Lyse Doucet takes the temperature on the streets of the Afghan capital as the Taliban tighten their grip.

item.title: Afghanistan: What rise of Taliban means for Pakistan
item.description: Some Western powers hope that Pakistan could play a role as a mediator with the new Taliban government.

item.title: Kabul drone strike: The key questions about a US attack
item.description: Ten Afghan civilians died when the US targeted a vehicle it says was linked to an imminent bombing.
